speaker: ELY
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The Presence chamber.

speaker: ELY
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY V, GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND, and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Where is my gracious Lord of Canterbury?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Not here in presence.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Send for him, good uncle.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Shall we call in the ambassador, my liege?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not yet, my cousin: we would be resolved,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Before we hear him, of some things of weight

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That task our thoughts, concerning us and France.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY, and the BISHOP of ELY

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: God and his angels guard your sacred throne

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And make you long become it!

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Sure, we thank you.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My learned lord, we pray you to proceed

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And justly and religiously unfold

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Why the law Salique that they have in France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or should, or should not, bar us in our claim:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That you should fashion, wrest, or bow your reading,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or nicely charge your understanding soul

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With opening titles miscreate, whose right

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Suits not in native colours with the truth;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For God doth know how many now in health

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall drop their blood in approbation

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of what your reverence shall incite us to.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore take heed how you impawn our person,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How you awake our sleeping sword of war:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We charge you, in the name of God, take heed;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For never two such kingdoms did contend

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Without much fall of blood; whose guiltless drops

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Are every one a woe, a sore complaint

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: 'Gainst him whose wrong gives edge unto the swords

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That make such waste in brief mortality.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Under this conjuration, speak, my lord;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For we will hear, note and believe in heart

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That what you speak is in your conscience wash'd

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As pure as sin with baptism.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: That owe yourselves, your lives and services

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To this imperial throne. There is no bar

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To make against your highness' claim to France

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: But this, which they produce from Pharamond,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: 'In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant:'

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: 'No woman shall succeed in Salique land:'

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Which Salique land the French unjustly gloze

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To be the realm of France, and Pharamond

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The founder of this law and female bar.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Yet their own authors faithfully affirm

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: That the land Salique is in Germany,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Between the floods of Sala and of Elbe;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Where Charles the Great, having subdued the Saxons,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: There left behind and settled certain French;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who, holding in disdain the German women

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: For some dishonest manners of their life,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Establish'd then this law; to wit, no female

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Should be inheritrix in Salique land:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Which Salique, as I said, 'twixt Elbe and Sala,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Is at this day in Germany call'd Meisen.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Then doth it well appear that Salique law

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Was not devised for the realm of France:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Nor did the French possess the Salique land

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Until four hundred one and twenty years

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: After defunction of King Pharamond,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Idly supposed the founder of this law;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who died within the year of our redemption

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Four hundred twenty-six; and Charles the Great

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Subdued the Saxons, and did seat the French

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Beyond the river Sala, in the year

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Eight hundred five. Besides, their writers say,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: King Pepin, which deposed Childeric,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Did, as heir general, being descended

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Make claim and title to the crown of France.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To find his title with some shows of truth,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: 'Through, in pure truth, it was corrupt and naught,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Convey'd himself as heir to the Lady Lingare,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Daughter to Charlemain, who was the son

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To Lewis the emperor, and Lewis the son

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Of Charles the Great. Also King Lewis the Tenth,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Could not keep quiet in his conscience,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Was re-united to the crown of France.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: So that, as clear as is the summer's sun.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: King Pepin's title and Hugh Capet's claim,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: King Lewis his satisfaction, all appear

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To hold in right and title of the female:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: So do the kings of France unto this day;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Howbeit they would hold up this Salique law

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To bar your highness claiming from the female,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And rather choose to hide them in a net

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Than amply to imbar their crooked titles

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Usurp'd from you and your progenitors.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: May I with right and conscience make this claim?

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The sin upon my head, dread sovereign!

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: For in the book of Numbers is it writ,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: When the man dies, let the inheritance

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Descend unto the daughter. Gracious lord,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Stand for your own; unwind your bloody flag;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Look back into your mighty ancestors:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Go, my dread lord, to your great-grandsire's tomb,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: From whom you claim; invoke his warlike spirit,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And your great-uncle's, Edward the Black Prince,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who on the French ground play'd a tragedy,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Making defeat on the full power of France,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Whiles his most mighty father on a hill

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Stood smiling to behold his lion's whelp

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Forage in blood of French nobility.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: O noble English. that could entertain

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: With half their forces the full Pride of France

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And let another half stand laughing by,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: All out of work and cold for action!

speaker: ELY
text_entry: Awake remembrance of these valiant dead

speaker: ELY
text_entry: And with your puissant arm renew their feats:

speaker: ELY
text_entry: You are their heir; you sit upon their throne;

speaker: ELY
text_entry: The blood and courage that renowned them

speaker: ELY
text_entry: Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege

speaker: ELY
text_entry: Is in the very May-morn of his youth,

speaker: ELY
text_entry: Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Your brother kings and monarchs of the earth

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Do all expect that you should rouse yourself,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: As did the former lions of your blood.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: They know your grace hath cause and means and might;

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: So hath your highness; never king of England

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Had nobles richer and more loyal subjects,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And lie pavilion'd in the fields of France.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: O, let their bodies follow, my dear liege,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: With blood and sword and fire to win your right;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: In aid whereof we of the spiritualty

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Will raise your highness such a mighty sum

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As never did the clergy at one time

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Bring in to any of your ancestors.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We must not only arm to invade the French,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But lay down our proportions to defend

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Against the Scot, who will make road upon us

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With all advantages.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: They of those marches, gracious sovereign,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Shall be a wall sufficient to defend

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Our inland from the pilfering borderers.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We do not mean the coursing snatchers only,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But fear the main intendment of the Scot,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Who hath been still a giddy neighbour to us;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For you shall read that my great-grandfather

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Never went with his forces into France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But that the Scot on his unfurnish'd kingdom

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Came pouring, like the tide into a breach,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With ample and brim fulness of his force,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Galling the gleaned land with hot assays,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Girding with grievous siege castles and towns;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That England, being empty of defence,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Hath shook and trembled at the ill neighbourhood.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: She hath been then more fear'd than harm'd, my liege;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: For hear her but exampled by herself:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: When all her chivalry hath been in France

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And she a mourning widow of her nobles,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: She hath herself not only well defended

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: But taken and impounded as a stray

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The King of Scots; whom she did send to France,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To fill King Edward's fame with prisoner kings

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And make her chronicle as rich with praise

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As is the ooze and bottom of the sea

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: With sunken wreck and sunless treasuries.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: But there's a saying very old and true,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: 'If that you will France win,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Then with Scotland first begin:'

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: For once the eagle England being in prey,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Playing the mouse in absence of the cat,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: To tear and havoc more than she can eat.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: It follows then the cat must stay at home:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Yet that is but a crush'd necessity,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Since we have locks to safeguard necessaries,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And pretty traps to catch the petty thieves.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: While that the armed hand doth fight abroad,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The advised head defends itself at home;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For government, though high and low and lower,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Put into parts, doth keep in one consent,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Congreeing in a full and natural close,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Like music.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Therefore doth heaven divide

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The state of man in divers functions,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Setting endeavour in continual motion;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To which is fixed, as an aim or butt,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Obedience: for so work the honey-bees,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Creatures that by a rule in nature teach

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The act of order to a peopled kingdom.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: They have a king and officers of sorts;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Where some, like magistrates, correct at home,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Others, like merchants, venture trade abroad,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Others, like soldiers, armed in their stings,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Make boot upon the summer's velvet buds,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Which pillage they with merry march bring home

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To the tent-royal of their emperor;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Who, busied in his majesty, surveys

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The singing masons building roofs of gold,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The civil citizens kneading up the honey,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The poor mechanic porters crowding in

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Their heavy burdens at his narrow gate,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The sad-eyed justice, with his surly hum,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Delivering o'er to executors pale

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The lazy yawning drone. I this infer,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: That many things, having full reference

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: To one consent, may work contrariously:

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many arrows, loosed several ways,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Come to one mark; as many ways meet in one town;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: As many lines close in the dial's centre;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: So may a thousand actions, once afoot.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: End in one purpose, and be all well borne

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Without defeat. Therefore to France, my liege.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Divide your happy England into four;

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Whereof take you one quarter into France,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: And you withal shall make all Gallia shake.

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: If we, with thrice such powers left at home,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Cannot defend our own doors from the dog,

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: Let us be worried and our nation lose

speaker: CANTERBURY
text_entry: The name of hardiness and policy.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt some Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now are we well resolved; and, by God's help,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And yours, the noble sinews of our power,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: France being ours, we'll bend it to our awe,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or break it all to pieces: or there we'll sit,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Ruling in large and ample empery

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: O'er France and all her almost kingly dukedoms,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Or lay these bones in an unworthy urn,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tombless, with no remembrance over them:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Either our history shall with full mouth

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Speak freely of our acts, or else our grave,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Like Turkish mute, shall have a tongueless mouth,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not worshipp'd with a waxen epitaph.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter Ambassadors of France

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Of our fair cousin Dauphin; for we hear

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Your greeting is from him, not from the king.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: May't please your majesty to give us leave

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Freely to render what we have in charge;

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Or shall we sparingly show you far off

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: The Dauphin's meaning and our embassy?

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Unto whose grace our passion is as subject

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: As are our wretches fetter'd in our prisons:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore with frank and with uncurbed plainness

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell us the Dauphin's mind.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Thus, then, in few.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Your highness, lately sending into France,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Did claim some certain dukedoms, in the right

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Of your great predecessor, King Edward the Third.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: In answer of which claim, the prince our master

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Says that you savour too much of your youth,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: And bids you be advised there's nought in France

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: That can be with a nimble galliard won;

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: You cannot revel into dukedoms there.

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: He therefore sends you, meeter for your spirit,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: This tun of treasure; and, in lieu of this,

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim

speaker: First Ambassador
text_entry: Hear no more of you. This the Dauphin speaks.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: What treasure, uncle?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Tennis-balls, my liege.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: His present and your pains we thank you for:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When we have march'd our rackets to these balls,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We will, in France, by God's grace, play a set

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall strike his father's crown into the hazard.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell him he hath made a match with such a wrangler

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That all the courts of France will be disturb'd

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: With chaces. And we understand him well,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: How he comes o'er us with our wilder days,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Not measuring what use we made of them.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We never valued this poor seat of England;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And therefore, living hence, did give ourself

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To barbarous licence; as 'tis ever common

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That men are merriest when they are from home.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But tell the Dauphin I will keep my state,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be like a king and show my sail of greatness

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When I do rouse me in my throne of France:

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For that I have laid by my majesty

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And plodded like a man for working-days,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But I will rise there with so full a glory

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That I will dazzle all the eyes of France,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Yea, strike the Dauphin blind to look on us.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And tell the pleasant prince this mock of his

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Hath turn'd his balls to gun-stones; and his soul

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall stand sore charged for the wasteful vengeance

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That shall fly with them: for many a thousand widows

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Shall this his mock mock out of their dear husbands;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Mock mothers from their sons, mock castles down;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: And some are yet ungotten and unborn

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That shall have cause to curse the Dauphin's scorn.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: But this lies all within the will of God,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To whom I do appeal; and in whose name

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Tell you the Dauphin I am coming on,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: To venge me as I may and to put forth

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: My rightful hand in a well-hallow'd cause.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: So get you hence in peace; and tell the Dauphin

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: His jest will savour but of shallow wit,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: When thousands weep more than did laugh at it.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Convey them with safe conduct. Fare you well.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt Ambassadors

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: This was a merry message.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We hope to make the sender blush at it.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore, my lords, omit no happy hour

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That may give furtherance to our expedition;

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: For we have now no thought in us but France,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Save those to God, that run before our business.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore let our proportions for these wars

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Be soon collected and all things thought upon

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That may with reasonable swiftness add

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: More feathers to our wings; for, God before,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: We'll chide this Dauphin at his father's door.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Therefore let every man now task his thought,

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: That this fair action may on foot be brought.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Exeunt. Flourish
